results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life.” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label: The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life.

results.title: Canopy
results.credit_line:
John Harvey, Saibai Island

Multi-screen installation

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe
results.brief_description: John Harvey’s multi-screen installation, Canopy, celebrates and shares First Peoples self-representation while resisting and disrupting popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood too often defined by the white gaze of non-Indigenous filmmakers.

constellations_primary.name: Canopy
constellations_primary.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

results.description:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey
description_for_label:
Throughout the history of screen culture, First Peoples have been portrayed as both an exotic curiosity and stereotypically deficient due to the ‘white gaze’ wielded by non-Indigenous Australians, who often defined First Peoples representation on-screen.

Around the 1970s, First Peoples stepped behind the camera en masse to capture their own story and control their representation, using the lens to return the gaze, look back, and look at each other. While celebrating, practicing and sharing culture, this gaze continues to resist and disrupt popular ideas of Australian identity, place and nationhood.

Canopy continues this tradition and comments on First Peoples self-representation.

“The canopy is teeming with life. It is a place where the biodiversity of species ensures the survival of us all. Through the imagery in my work, I’m exploring layers of being, from the individual to family, clan, culture, country and finally, to consciousness. Canopy invites audiences to still their minds and experience the work as a meditation with an open spirit and heart. It contains my home movies along with films I’ve written and directed.” – John Harvey

Commissioned by ACMI and edited by Patrick McCabe

results.title: [George Robinson Parsons Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The George Robinson Parsons Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 16mm AGFA film. George Robinson (Robin) Parsons was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies on a Bolex camera during the period 1929 to 1938. The home movies show life in Melbourne and regional Victoria in the 1930s.

This film shows an example of life in Victoria, Australia, just prior to the Second World War. Much of it revolves around members of the Parsons family and friends who are clearly not camera shy. In a number of scenes, you can see individuals playing up to the camera. There is even a staged boxing match on the beach where Robin (George Robinson) Parsons experimented with using special effects.

The film shows several Victorian locations including Melbourne, Dromana, Rosebud Aerodrome, Cape Schanck, Mt Hotham, Mallacoota, Wangarrata and Yallourn. Dromana Beach is featured a few times and appears to be a family favourite for swimming and family gatherings.

This film is rich with fashion of the period, both casual and formal, including two weddings of different periods and golfing attire.

Included in the film is the 1935 centennial celebrations parade showing crowded street with brass bands travelling down Collins Street, including a brief scene of an Aboriginal float. Much of these scenes are taken from the rooftop of Parsons Bros and company building. The company would later form Uncle Toby’s.

The film also includes the Shrine of Remembrance, St Pauls cathedral, Princes Bridge and many other Melbourne landmarks including some buildings and sites that no longer exist.

Of interest are the many forms of transport that are seen throughout which include cars, trams, horses, bicycles, motor bike with side carriage, a canoe, bi planes, fighter planes, a gyrocopter, the Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane (only 12 were ever created), transport planes, steamboats, tugboats, a navy ship, locomotives and a Melbourne ferry.

Also of interest is a scene from the 1939 Australian Championship at Kooyong Stadium with John Bromwich and Adrian Quist.

Selected Highlights List
00:00:02:00 – Geoffrey and Jean Parsons playing with a Fox Terrier
00:01:12:00 – Wedding of Mary Dowling Woods and John Bedggood
00:02:07:00 – Melbourne Grammar Sports day at the MCG
00:03:52:00 – The Rose family, Aeneas Gunn and Robin Parsons at the Rose family home with dogs
00:05:10:00 – Doug Rose and Aeneas Gunn riding a cow
00:07:34:00 – Steam boat on the Yarra River
00:07:48:00 – Parson family and friends swimming at Dromana beach showing 1930’s swimming costumes
00:08:44:00 Sidney and Susannah Parsons at Dromana Beach
00:09:53:00 – Parsons family doing Acrobats, playing games and making a human tower at Dromana Beach
00:10:55:00 – Bi Planes – VH–UHR, VH-UHS and VH-UAT
00:12:23:00 – Two women and Geoffrey Parsons on a rug in the garden of the family home
00:14:01:00 – Susannah Parsons demonstrating her golfing swing
00:14:52:00 – View of Princes bridge with Flinders Street Railway station in the Background
00:15:20:00 – View towards the Flinders street Fish Market (demolished in 1956)
00:15:26:00 – Steam boats docked on the Yarra river.
00:15:46:00 – Navy ship in the harbour
00:16:06:00 – The shrine of Remembrance (before the gardens were there) and views of Melbourne from its balcony.
00:21:28:00 – View of Collins Street from the roof of the Parson Bros Mill near Spencer street station, showing the 1935 centennial celebrations parade
00:22:45:00 – Sidney Parsons, Robin Parsons and unknown man playing golf
00:23:56:00 - View from the rooftop of Parsons Bros Mill on Collins Street looking up towards the Victorian Railway administration offices on Spencer street and down Flinders Lane.
00:24:20:00 – People lining Nicholson street (near parliament gardens) to watch lavish floats and masked performers.
00:30:56:00 – Parson family members at the beach in Dromana
00:37:24:00 – Doug and Charlie Parsons climbing the sign labelled the highest house in Australia at Hotham Heights and camping trip
00:42:30:00 – Front view of motorbike with side car following on the road in wet weather
00:27:23:00 – Parson brothers, friends and fiancée Jean, on the coast of Cape Shanck.
00:42:59:00 – Jean Parsons (portrait view)
00:43:03:00 – Robin Parsons (portrait view) smoking
00:43:18:00 – 1939 Australian Championship, Kooyong Stadium – John Bromwich and Adrian Quist
00:43:56:00 – Wedding of unknown couple
00:44:42:00 – VH-USQ Cierva C.30A Auto gyro (Gyrocopter)
00:46:37:00 – The Saro A17 Cutty Sark seaplane off Dromana Beach. Geoffrey Parsons climbing out of the Cockpit. (VH-UNV)
00:47:51:00 – Douglas DC-2 Airliner VH-USY “Bungana” outside Holymans hangar at Melbourne/Essendon airport
00:48:24:00 – Miles M-3 Merlin (VH-UXN) (Came to Australia in 1936)
00:48:41:00 – De Havilland D.H. 86A express (VH-UUB) Loila outside Holymans Hanger at Melbourne Essendon airport
00:53:23:00 – Rifle shooting in the snow at Mount Hotham

results.title: VFX in Peter Rabbit
results.credit_line:
PR1: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™, the Movie ©2018 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
PR2: PETER RABBIT and all associated characters ™ & © Frederick Warne & Co Limited. PETER RABBIT™ 2:The Runaway, the Movie ©2021 Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
results.brief_description: A look at how acclaimed VFX studio Animal Logic bought Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit to life.

constellations_primary.name: VFX to fantasy and freedom
constellations_primary.description: Founded in Sydney, and now with offices worldwide, Animal Logic are an Academy Award-winning VFX and animation studio whose job is to bring the impossible to life. And they're in good company with these other artists and filmmakers.

results.description: First springing from the mind of Beatrix Potter, Peter Rabbit is a creature that has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the beloved character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live action and animation for Peter Rabbit (2018), they used prop rabbits during the shoot so cast members had a tangible property to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
description_for_label: Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit has captured the imagination of children for more than a century. So there was plenty of pressure when it came to bringing the character to life on the big screen. Animal Logic rose to the occasion, with the Australian company having to get inventive. To achieve a seamless hybrid of live-action and animation for Peter Rabbit, they used prop rabbits during the shoot for cast members to interact with. In post-production, the Prop Peters were replaced with an animated version by visual effect artists.
results.credit_line_for_label:
PETER RABBIT™ & © FW&Co. PETER RABBIT™ Movie © 2021 CPII All Rights Reserved

Special thanks to Columbia Pictures

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: Screen Worlds opening : September 2009
results.brief_description:
On Thursday September 17, 2009 ACMI’s new permanent screen culture exhibition Screen Worlds, was officially launched. The red carpet, VIP event attracted world wide attention with the attendance of both internationally recognised and home grown guests and artists. Kicking off the formalities was ACMI’s Board President, John Thwaites, followed by ACMI Director Tony Sweeney, Oscar® Winning Actress Cate Blanchett, Victorian Arts Minister Lynne Kosky and Victorian Premier John Brumby.
Following this, the ribbon is cut and guests enter the exhibition for the first time.

results.title: Out of Sight, Out of Mind
results.creator_credit: David Goldie and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: ‘Out of Sight, Out of Mind’, in its depiction of prison conditions, helped to raise awareness about a much neglected section of our society. It provided extensive insight into the prison system, interviewing prisoners, prison officers and administrators. There are four parts titled ‘Locked Up’, ‘Surviving in the Nick’, ‘The Keepers and the Kept’, and ‘The Cycle of Crime’. This program pulls no punches, describes the conditions of various correctional institutions around Australia and also offers some suggestions for improvements.

results.title: Whereas the people
results.brief_description: Traces the development of the Australian Constitution and investigates its relevance for today as well as examining the politics behind its drafting. The continuous “battle” between State and Federal powers is illustrated by the Franklin Dam case and the process of Constitutional change through referendum is explained.

results.title: Rollergirl
results.brief_description: This performance art film features bluescreen technology with the director/actor rollerskating to background images of war, weapons and military might. No dialogue - music soundtrack.
